Title: How to properly use GAGA correspondence
Content:
currently studying algebraic surfaces over the complex numbers. Before i did some algebraic geometry (I,II,start of III of Hartshorne) and a course on Riemann surfaces. Now i understood that by GAGA, a lot of results transfer from complex analytic geometry to algebraic geometry over $\mathbb{C}$.
Question: in my RS surface course the genus for a compact RS was defined as the number of holes, formally half of the dimension of the first de rham cohomology group (or singular with coefficients in some field of characteristic zero).
Now i encountered the algebraic definition: the dimension of the first cohomology group of the structure sheaf. I expect them to be the same, but did not find a quick proof. Can anyone show me how this works? I learned that de rham cohomology with coefficients in $\mathbb{C}$ corresponds to sheaf cohomology of the constant sheaf $\mathbb{C}$. However i'm not sure, can someone either confirm this or tell me why it's not true? If it is true, i find it hard to work with, since up till now i've been basically using Serre duality and Riemann Roch for bundles to reduce computing homology to computing spaces of global sections, however since the constant sheaf is not locally free i cannot apply this trick (or can i?).
Also, the constant sheaf makes sense both algebraically and analytically, so which one should i take in the de rham <-> constant sheaf correspondence? Or do both work? (with GAGA in mind, i expect them to have the same cohomology, but this might not be true) So summarizing Do both definitions of genus agree? (of course assuming the algebraic curve to be smooth, so it is a RS) If they do, can you show me a proof? (preferably using some sheaf cohomology) Is it true that de rham cohomology corresponds to sheaf cohomology of the constant sheaf, if so is it the the analytic one, the algebraic one, or both? Am i limiting myself unnecessarily by using Riemann Roch and Serre duality just for bundles, i.e. can i use them for all sheaves? Lastly, when answering my questions, it would be immensely appreciated if you could elaborate a little on how to use GAGA in general. Hope this makes sense, i suspect them to be silly questions once i understand them, but right now it's a fuzz to me.. Joachim Edit: i just found a result from Hodge theory for surfaces in Beauville, stating $h^{0}(S,\Omega^1_S) = \frac{1}{2}h^{1}(S,\mathbb{R})$, all cohomology being analytic. So assuming (1) the same thing holds for curves and (2) GAGA identifies the algebraic and analytic cotangent bundle, Serre duality states that the left hand side is equal to $h^{1}(C,\mathcal{O}_C)$, i.e. the genus found in my AG textbook and i proved one thingwhat i wanted to proof. I was trying to find a reference on Hodge theory so i could verify (1) but a quick scan yielded no results. Does anyone have good idea on this? Also i was wondering about (2) for a longer time, i'd be really happy with any comments on this.
AcceptedAnswer:
First let me emphasize what Serre did : in 1956 he wrote  an article Géométrie algébrique et géométrie analytique , which everybody calls GAGA (I heard him explain that he deliberately chose the title so that this would happen!). This article proves many results, the gist of which is that calculations for coherent sheaves on a projective complex variety $X$  give the same (or isomorphic) results as those done on the underlying holomorphic  variety  $X^h$. However he did not consider non coherent sheaves and for good reason:  if for example you consider the constant sheaf $\mathbb C_X$ on $X$, it is flabby ("flasque") so that all its cohomology groups vanish: $H^i(X,\mathbb C_X)=0$, whereas of course the cohomology vector spaces $H^i(X^h,\mathbb C_{X^h})$    are not zero in general: For  example if $X$ is a smooth projective curve of genus $g$, then $X^h$ is a Riemann surface and $dim _\mathbb C H^1(X^h,\mathbb C_{X^h})=2g $. Fortunately thanks to the rich techniques known for holomorphic manifolds many apparently transcendental invariants of a projective smooth manifold can be computed using only coherent sheaves. A splendid example is Dolbeault's 1953 result for Betti numbers  $$b_r(X^h)=\sum_{p+q=r} dim_\mathbb C H^q (X^h,\Omega_{X^h}^p)$$ Since  the right hand size is cohomology of coherent sheaves,it can  be calculated algebraically thanks to GAGA: $$ dim_\mathbb C H^q (X^h,\Omega_{X^h}^p)=dim_\mathbb C H^q (X,\Omega_{X}^p) $$
In particular, for a smooth projective curve $X$, the genus of the associated Riemann surface $X^h$ is given algebraically by $$g(X^h)=\frac {1}{2}(b_1(X^h))=\frac {1}{2}(dim_\mathbb C H^1 (X,\mathcal O_X)+dim_\mathbb C H^0 (X,\Omega_{X}^1))$$ where the two summands on the right are equal by Serre duality (him again!). Warning This answer is meant  to address your request "it would be immensely appreciated if you could elaborate a little on how to use GAGA in general     ", not to show the shortest or most elementary road to technically answer your  questions on Riemann surfaces.

###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
$C$ is a smooth projective algebraic curve over $\mathbb{C}$,
The analytic genus is defined as $g_{an} = \frac{1}{2}\dim H^1_{dR}(C(\mathbb{C}), \mathbb{C})$,
The algebraic genus is defined as $g_{alg} = \dim H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C)$,
GAGA identifies algebraic coherent sheaves with analytic coherent sheaves for projective varieties over $\mathbb{C}$,
Hodge decomposition holds for compact Riemann surfaces (analytic setting).
Problem: 
Prove that $g_{an} = g_{alg}$. Additionally, clarify:  
1. Whether de Rham cohomology corresponds to sheaf cohomology of the constant sheaf $\mathbb{C}$ (analytically or algebraically),  
2. If Serre duality/Riemann-Roch apply to non-locally free sheaves (e.g., constant sheaves),  
3. How GAGA precisely bridges analytic and algebraic cohomology in this context.

reasoning_create_structured_problem:
Okay, so the user is asking about how the genus of a compact Riemann surface relates between the analytic definition (number of holes, first de Rham cohomology) and the algebraic definition (first cohomology of the structure sheaf). They also have several related questions about GAGA, sheaf cohomology, and applying Serre duality and Riemann-Roch to constant sheaves.

First, I need to parse their main problem. They want to know if the two definitions of genus agree. The analytic genus is half the dimension of the first de Rham cohomology (which, for a compact Riemann surface, should be equal to the singular cohomology with coefficients in C). The algebraic genus is the dimension of H^1(C, O_C), the first cohomology of the structure sheaf.

They mention GAGA, so I recall that GAGA theorems relate analytic and algebraic coherent sheaves on projective varieties. The structure sheaf in algebraic geometry corresponds to the analytic structure sheaf under GAGA, and their cohomologies should agree. 

They also brought up de Rham cohomology corresponding to sheaf cohomology with the constant sheaf C. In the analytic setting, de Rham's theorem says that de Rham cohomology is isomorphic to singular cohomology with C coefficients, which in turn is isomorphic to sheaf cohomology of the constant sheaf C. But in algebraic geometry, the constant sheaf isn't coherent, so GAGA doesn't directly apply. Hence, the user is confused about whether to take the analytic or algebraic constant sheaf.

They also asked about using Serre duality and Riemann-Roch for sheaves that aren't locally free. Serre duality typically applies to coherent sheaves, but for Riemann-Roch, usually, you need divisors or line bundles. The constant sheaf isn't locally free, so standard Riemann-Roch might not apply directly. However, on a curve, maybe there's a way to relate these?

In their edit, they mention using Hodge theory. For surfaces, h^{0}(S, Ω¹_S) = ½ h¹(S, R), and they want to check if this holds for curves. For curves, Hodge theory should say that H¹(C, C) decomposes into H⁰(C, Ω¹) ⊕ H¹(C, O), which are both equal in dimension. So the genus g satisfies 2g = dim H¹(C, C), hence each term on the right is g. Therefore, H¹(C, O) is g, matching the algebraic definition. But this uses analytic Hodge theory. GAGA would imply that the algebraic H¹(C, O) is the same as the analytic H¹(C^{an}, O^{an}), so combining with Hodge theory gives the equality of genera.

They also question whether the algebraic and analytic cotangent bundles are identified by GAGA. Since the cotangent sheaf is coherent, GAGA should indeed identify their cohomologies.

So the assumptions would include that the curve is smooth and projective (hence algebraic by GAGA), and working over C. The problem is to show the two genera agree using sheaf cohomology and GAGA. The user also has sub-questions about de Rham cohomology corresponding to constant sheaves, applicability of duality theorems, and using GAGA in general.
